author: By David Leonhardt
title: A new Times quiz
description: Test your knowledge of history.
content: Today, my colleagues at the Upshot section are introducing a beta version of a weekly history quiz. It’s called Flashback, and it’s free for all readers for a limited time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Anguish in Camelot: Kennedy Campaign Roils Storied Political Family
description: The presidential bid by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has tested the bonds of an iconic Democratic clan that does not want him to run and does not know what to do about it.
content: Jack Schlossberg had had enough. The only grandson of President John F. Kennedy, Mr. Schlossberg had been watching the presidential campaign of his cousin Robert F. Kennedy Jr. with increasing dismay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and Ana Swanson
title: Indiana Tests if the Heartland Can Transform Into a Chip Hub
description: The state has little experience with semiconductors, but the Biden administration has promised to unleash opportunity in “the heartland of America” through the $52 billion CHIPS Act.
content: Over the past 14 months, Indiana began converting 10,000 acres of corn and bean fields into an innovation park. State leaders met with the chief executives of semiconductor giants in South Korea, Taiwan and Japan. And they hosted top Biden administration officials to show off a $100 million expansion of chip research and development facilities at a local university.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: For Megan Rapinoe, an Ending Not Even She Could Have Imagined
description: A missed penalty kick was a cruel way to draw down the curtain on a star’s World Cup career. But her influence and legacy were never about soccer alone.
content: It ended in the most excruciating way for Megan Rapinoe: a penalty kick skied over the crossbar, shock, disappointment, a rueful smile to herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Barbie’ Reaches $1 Billion at the Box Office, Studio Says
description: No movie in Warner Bros. history has sold so many tickets so fast, the studio said of the movie directed by Greta Gerwig.
content: In the history of Hollywood, very few people — 28 to be precise, all men — have had the sole directing credit on a billion-dollar movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Kolker, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and Lance Neal
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Vanishing Family: Life in the Shadow of a Cruel Genetic Mutation’
description: They all have a 50-50 chance of inheriting a terrible genetic mutation — which means disappearing into dementia in middle age. This is the story of what it’s like to live with those odds.
content: When Barb’s father all but left, her mother turned inward, sitting quietly in front of the television, always smoking, often with a cocktail. Something had overtaken her, though it wasn’t clear what.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Back in Competition, It’s as if Simone Biles Never Left
description: Biles won the U.S. Classic by 5 points in her return to elite gymnastics, after she withdrew from the Tokyo Olympics in 2021.
content: It did not look like Simone Biles had been gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Automakers Face a Labor Showdown as the E.V. Era Looms
description: The United Auto Workers leader vowed to be tougher than his predecessors in contract talks. His initial demands attach big numbers to that promise.
content: Detroit may be headed for a tumultuous labor showdown.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Houston Volunteers Fight Tickets for Serving Meals to Homeless People
description: A Food Not Bombs chapter faces $23,500 in fines for serving meals to homeless people in violation of a city ordinance.
content: A volunteer group that has been feeding homeless people in Houston with heaping plates of rice, fresh fruit and vegetables outside the city’s library for more than a decade is fighting a local law that could cost $23,500 in fines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: At Least 24 Killed in Minibus Crash in Morocco
description: The vehicle overturned at a curve on its way to a weekly town market southeast of Marrakesh, officials said.
content: RABAT, Morocco — At least 24 people died Sunday in a bus crash in central Morocco, in one of the deadliest such accidents in recent years in the country, which has a poor road safety record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Franklin
title: When the Favor of a Beloved Schoolteacher Turns Sinister
description: In Catherine Chidgey’s seventh novel, “Pet,” a motherless 12-year-old girl falls under the intoxicating spell of a mysterious teacher at her Catholic school in New Zealand.
content: Contemporary books about adolescent girls tend to fall into two categories. First, the reassuring kind, by Norma Klein or Judy Blume, in which the bad things that happen are the usual ones — puberty, parental divorce, bullying — and everything will be all right in the end. Then there’s the other kind, by writers like Shirley Jackson or Elena Ferrante. In these, the primary revelation of adolescence is the girl’s discovery of her own power — a power difficult to control, which can hurt or even kill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: In Egypt, Public Classrooms Are Empty as Private Tutors Get Rich
description: In a country hobbled by economic crisis, families often turn to private education centers instead of schools to seek better futures for their children, sometimes even sacrificing food to pay for lessons.
content: Asked what classes were like in her last year of high school, the fateful period when students across the country cram for Egypt’s life-defining national exams, Nermin Abouzeid looked blank for a second.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Tour That Shook the Earth, and a Star on Top of the World
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 6, 2023.
content: “This year I decided not to freeze my eggs. I’m going to put that money toward the thing I love most in the world, which is Taylor Swift.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Zia ur-Rehman
title: Train Derails in Pakistan, Killing at Least 30
description: An express train carrying at least 950 passengers was traveling from Karachi to Havelian when 10 carriages fell off the tracks, officials said.
content: At least 30 people were killed and dozens of others injured on Sunday after an express train derailed in southern Pakistan, officials said, thrusting the dilapidated state of the country’s railway infrastructure back into the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Siyi Zhao
title: Why ‘Barbie’ Became a Sleeper Hit in China
description: The movie has exceeded box office expectations, as China’s female moviegoers celebrate a film that addresses women’s rights head-on.
content: There were plenty of reasons to think the “Barbie” movie might have a hard time finding an audience in China. It’s an American film, when Chinese moviegoers’ interest in, and government approval of, Hollywood movies is falling. It’s been widely described as feminist, when women’s rights and political representation in China are backsliding.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 6, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 6, 2023.
content: An article on Page 1 this weekend about the First Response fire chasers misstates Jatiek Smith’s age. He was 35 in 2019, not 33.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin and Eduardo Medina
title: What We Know About the Chaos Caused by a Twitch Star’s Giveaway
description: The popular social media streamer Kai Cenat was charged with inciting a riot on Friday after his event in Manhattan’s Union Square Park descended into mayhem.
content: A gathering of thousands of people in Manhattan’s Union Square Park on Friday quickly became an unruly scene, with dozens of police officers called to quell the chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: My Hope for American Discourse
description: Public engagement must be balanced with times of withdrawal and silence.
content: I know friends who prefer to slip out unseen from jobs, relationships or parties, a so-called Irish goodbye. I, on the other hand, need closure, slide show retrospectives, debriefing, confessional reflections, post-mortem relationship analysis, final words, rituals of departure. I need to go to the funeral. I need closing ceremonies when I move out of houses or cities. When I am leaving on a trip, I hug my kids like I’ll never return, even when they are too young to understand what’s happening or too old and cool to care much. I need goodbyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: How the U.S. Was Eliminated From the World Cup, Shot by Shot
description: The shootout was rapid-fire but still agonizing for both Sweden, which moved to the quarterfinals, and the United States, which was eliminated.
content: Under an ink black Australian sky above Melbourne Rectangular Stadium, the Women’s World Cup game between the United States and Sweden on Sunday went on and on and on. For 120 minutes, it went on as the teams tried unsuccessfully to score, with nearly 28,000 fans so nervous that they could only muster a simmer of cheers. Until penalty kicks turned up the volume and decided it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Netherlands Holds Off South Africa, Squeezing Into World Cup Quarterfinals
description: A goal in each half delivered victory, and a date with Spain. But a South Africa striker made the day as difficult as possible.
content: Thembi Kgatlana had time to pull off one more trick, to take one more shot, to send one more jolt of electricity through the crowd. She had been running, by that stage, for roughly 100 minutes, mounting what appeared at times to be a fearsome, one-woman campaign to keep South Africa in the Women’s World Cup for as long as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Kamala Harris Takes on a Forceful New Role in the 2024 Campaign
description: The vice president is trying to reclaim the momentum that propelled her to Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s side as a candidate and into the White House in 2020.
content: In recent weeks, Vice President Kamala Harris has dashed off to Florida on short notice. She sparred with the state’s conservative governor, Ron DeSantis, over how to teach slavery in schools. And she flew into Iowa to defend abortion rights while 13 Republican presidential candidates were having dinner a few miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Lush, Buttery, Perfect Peach Crisp
description: Don’t worry if your peaches are subpar — summer’s favorite stone fruit shines when baked under a blanket of crisp golden oats.
content: Good morning. Games that my family plays on road trips: Punch Buggy, Stump the Teacher, I’m Thinking of an Animal. Also, the Rating Game: your top five sandwiches, your top five pizzerias, your top five restaurant dishes, your top five fruits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Heat Waves Are Killing Older Women. Are They Also Violating Their Rights?
description: A group of Swiss women over 64 has filed a lawsuit against Switzerland with Europe’s top human rights court, saying the country has violated their rights by failing to curb emissions.
content: The women live scattered around Switzerland, speak a mix of the country’s languages — German, French and Italian — and have worked in varying professions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: How to Catch Pandemic Fraud? Prosecutors Try Novel Methods.
description: Strained by limited resources, prosecutors are deploying special teams and nurturing local relationships to catch up to a wave of fraud.
content: Federal prosecutors are scrambling to recoup billions of dollars in pandemic aid from people who falsely obtained funds from government programs that were intended to keep the economy afloat during the Covid shutdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Feeling of Deep Anxiety
description: Chloe Revery and Alissa Revness have crafted a frightfully fun puzzle.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Soccer’s Favorite Headband Is Supposed to Go Around Your Ankle
description: Pre-wrap, a type of medical gauze intended for injured joints, has found a second life as stylish headwear in women’s soccer and other sports.
content: Alex Morgan can easily rattle off the colors of the headbands worn by her United States teammates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Omar Hama Saley
title: War, Mediation or Silence? Deadline for Coup Leaders in Niger Passes.
description: A deadline given by a bloc of other West African nations to the Nigerien military junta to reinstate the ousted president ran out with no sign of a military intervention by neighbors.
content: Stocking up on rice, fleeing the capital by bus or vowing to defend their new military leaders, many in Niger braced this weekend for a deadline imposed by a 15-member bloc of West African nations for the country’s junta to relinquish power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: With No Date Set, Musk and Zuckerberg Trade Barbs on ‘Cage Match’
description: Elon Musk, in an early-morning post, said he planned to livestream the event on his own platform. Mark Zuckerberg called for a “more reliable” platform, adding, “I’m ready today.”
content: For months, the chatter in Silicon Valley has centered on whether Mark Zuckerberg and Elon Musk would actually participate in a “cage match” as they said they would. But after a flurry of activity and promises from both sides, it looked as if the momentum behind the mega-mogul face-off had fizzled out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie V. Iovine
title: Dog Parks Are Great for People. Too Bad They’re Terrible for Dogs.
description: It’s not an oasis. It’s a thunderdome for pooches.
content: For urban dog owners with a live-wire canine bouncing off the apartment walls, an enclosed dog park can feel like an oasis, offering off-the-leash exercise, an outlet for excess energy, a social experience for the dog and, often, for the humans, too. In fact, dog parks are perfect, save for one small thing: They are bad for dogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danez Smith
title: James McBride’s Latest Is a Murder Mystery Inside a Great American Novel
description: “The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store” opens with the discovery of a skeleton in a well, and then flashes back to explore its connection to a town’s Black, Jewish and immigrant history.
content: A few weeks ago, around the same time I was working on this review, I visited the Guggenheim with my fiancé. The exhibition on display as we trekked up the museum’s famous spiral was “Measuring Infinity,” a marvelous retrospective on the work of the great Venezuelan artist Gego. A German Jew who fled Nazi persecution in Europe, Gego arrived in Venezuela in 1939 and went on to become one of the most important artists to emerge from Latin America in the 20th century. Her work speaks to a deep curiosity about the interrelation of shapes, things and the dimensions created by those relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Are G.O.P. Voters Tiring of the War on ‘Wokeness’?
description: New polling shows national Republicans and Iowa Republican caucusgoers were more interested in “law and order” than battling “woke” schools, media and corporations.
content: When it comes to the Republican primaries, attacks on “wokeness” may be losing their punch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Duane
title: It’s August. Californians Are Still Skiing. Don’t Ask.
description: Unpredictable climate change is the new status quo.
content: This weekend, while I squeeze into a thick winter wet suit for a cold-water surf in foggy San Francisco — and while my cousin in Phoenix goes rock climbing indoors to escape 115-degree heat — hordes of Californians are smearing pink and yellow zinc oxide on noses, shoving feet into hard plastic ski boots and gliding over to the lifts at Mammoth Mountain for yet another day on the slopes. A reminder: It’s August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Our Galaxy Is Home to Trillions of Worlds Gone Rogue
description: Astronomers have found that free-floating planets far outnumber those bound to a host star.
content: Free-floating planets — dark, isolated orbs roaming the universe unfettered to any host star — don’t just pop into existence in the middle of cosmic nowhere. They probably form the same way other planets do: within the swirling disk of gas and dust surrounding an infant star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Nanna Heitmann
title: Putin’s Forever War
description: Vladimir Putin wants to lead Russians into a civilizational conflict with the West far larger than Ukraine. Will they follow him?
content: Through towering pine forests and untouched meadows, the road to Lake Baikal in southern Siberia winds past cemeteries where bright plastic flowers mark the graves of Russians killed in Ukraine. Far from the Potemkin paradise of Moscow, the war is ever visible.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Pathway I Was Walking on Was Next to a Fenced-In Basketball Court’
description: A buzzing sound uptown, undecided about dinner and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: A Lightbulb Went Off
description: I get that we have to let incandescents go, but the chilly, shrill light of their replacements doesn’t compare.
content: When Thomas Edison was working on the incandescent lamp in 1879, he purportedly said, “We are striking it big in the electric light, better than my vivid imagination first conceived. Where this thing is going to stop, Lord only knows.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Pulse Massacre Victims File Police Complaints Saying Exits Were Blocked
description: Questions about the Orlando nightclub where a shooting occurred in 2016 have persisted. Now survivors want to know: Were there adequate paths to escape?
content: On the night that the Pulse nightclub in Orlando was attacked by a gunman with a high-capacity rifle, Jorshua Hernández spent three hours bleeding in a bathroom stall, unable to find his way to an exit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivek Shankar and Anushka Patil
title: Ukraine Strikes 2 Bridges Connected to Russian-Occupied Crimea
description: Ukraine has grown bolder, firing drones at Moscow, while Russian forces have turned to regular attacks on the Black Sea, a crucial economic lifeline.
content: Ukrainian forces struck two bridges connecting Russian-occupied Crimea to the rest of Ukraine on Sunday, part of a broader pattern of attacks on and around the peninsula that has sought to scramble critical supply routes for the Kremlin and push the scope of the war into fresh territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: 7 Campers Critically Injured in Bus Crash in Idaho
description: A school bus with about 30 passengers rolled over on a winding highway north of Boise on Friday, the police said.
content: A school bus carrying about 30 campers rolled over on a winding highway north of Boise, Idaho, on Friday, leaving seven of the passengers critically injured, according to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: At Bessie Awards, Mourning and Celebration
description: Joyce Edwards, Dormeshia and J. Bouey were among the winners. The ceremony included a tribute to O’Shae Sibley, the dancer who was killed in July.
content: A flurry of teenage dancers opened the New York Dance and Performance Awards, better known as the Bessies, on Friday night at Lincoln Center’s Damrosch Park in Manhattan. Set to a backdrop of Lady Gaga’s “Born This Way,” the dancers, from the Brooklyn-based group Diversity of Dance, bounced, leaped and grooved down the aisles through the crowd before taking the stage. Arms were thrown in the air; elbows flung side to side; bodies shook in exuberant celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: Khan Arrested in Pakistan
description: Also, diverted floodwaters provoke anger in China.
content: Imran Khan, the former prime minister of Pakistan, was taken into custody and sentenced to three years in prison on Saturday after a court found him guilty of illegally selling state gifts and concealing the assets. The verdict will most likely end his chances of running in general elections, set for this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry and Brittainy Newman
title: Summer Camp: Sun, Swimming, Archery. And Therapy.
description: As the United States grapples with a mental-health crisis, summer camps are looking more closely at the children in their care.
content: Heather Klein was in her cabin at Camp Nah-Jee-Wah, nursing her first iced tea of the morning, when a photograph arrived on her phone and she drew a deep, sudden breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: The Fight Over the Dune Shacks of Cape Cod: No Power, No Water — but Eugene O’Neill Was Here
description: The shacks have been cared for by locals, activists and artists. Now the National Park Service plans to lease them to bidders.
content: Here at the far edge of Cape Cod, where hills of white sand border a vast and empty shore, 19 rough-hewed shacks — tiny and unadorned, with no electricity or running water — sit within a windswept federal preserve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Mourners Pay Tribute to O’Shae Sibley at the Scene of His Murder
description: “Vogueing is not a crime,” an activist said, before the crowd danced through the city streets in honor of the slain dancer.
content: Hundreds of mourners gathered on Friday at the Brooklyn gas station where O’Shae Sibley, a 28-year-old dancer and choreographer, was fatally stabbed last weekend after a dispute over his vogueing in its parking lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: A Real Estate Reporter Interested in Interest Envy
description: Ronda Kaysen recently wrote about a kind of one-upmanship born out of the pandemic: gloating over mortgage rates.
content: In July, Ronda Kaysen, a Real Estate reporter for The New York Times, put out a call to readers. She wanted to learn how homeowners and prospective buyers felt about their mortgage rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Barbecues, Fairs and Weddings: Ron DeSantis Amps Up Retail Politics in Iowa
description: The Florida governor, who has struggled at times to connect with voters, is looking for every opportunity to show he is all-in with Iowa Republicans.
content: Two great traditions converged in Des Moines on Saturday night when wedding crashing came to Iowa politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Astor
title: Trump Calls for Judge’s Recusal as His Lawyer Deems Effort to Overturn Election ‘Aspirational’
description: Former President Donald J. Trump spent the weekend on the attack on Truth Social while his lawyer, John F. Lauro, ran through a gantlet of interviews Sunday morning.
content: Appearing on five television networks Sunday morning, a lawyer for former President Donald J. Trump argued that his actions in the effort to overturn the 2020 election fell short of crimes and were merely “aspirational.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: The N.B.A. Player Who Might See His Mom at Union Meetings
description: Jaren Jackson Jr. is active in the N.B.A. players’ union. His mother, Terri, works for the W.N.B.A. players’ union. When he was elected vice president, she did her best not to embarrass him.
content: The National Basketball Players Association is the union for N.B.A. players, a group of adult millionaires, most of whose mothers don’t attend unit meetings.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Woman, Teens and a Viral Video
description: Readers respond to the video of a dispute between a white woman and Black teens over a bike. Also: Racial bias in U.S. immigration policy; Melania Trump.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: California Judge Arrested in Connection With Killing of His Wife, Police Say
description: The wife of Judge Jeffrey Ferguson of Orange County Superior Court was found fatally shot inside their Anaheim home on Thursday, the police said.
content: A Southern California judge was arrested on Thursday in connection with the killing of his wife, whom police officers found dead from a gunshot wound inside the couple’s Anaheim home, the authorities said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Eight Months Pregnant and Arrested After False Facial Recognition Match
description: Porcha Woodruff thought the police who showed up at her door to arrest her for carjacking were joking. She is the first woman known to be wrongfully accused as a result of facial recognition technology.
content: Porcha Woodruff was getting her two daughters ready for school when six police officers showed up at her door in Detroit. They asked her to step outside because she was under arrest for robbery and carjacking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: Woman Dies After Recent Mass Attack in South Korea
description: The victim was one of 14 people hurt in a car-and-stabbing rampage on Thursday in a city near Seoul. She had been hit by the car.
content: A victim from Thursday’s car rampage and stabbing in South Korea was declared dead early Sunday morning, according to officials, the first fatality in the attack, which had injured 14 people and unsettled a nation where mass violence is uncommon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Braidwood
title: Alessia Russo Is Ready for Her Next Big Moment
description: The England striker scored her first World Cup goal last week. She is just getting started.
content: The secret of the goal that announced Alessia Russo to the world, the out-of-nowhere backheel that stunned Sweden during England’s run to the European Championship last summer, was that Russo wasn’t sure it would happen. That the ball went in the net was, in her words, “maybe luck, maybe instinct.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: At Santa Fe Opera, the Oldest Work Is Also the Freshest
description: Among the company’s annual summer offerings, Monteverdi’s “L’Orfeo,” from 1607 but newly reorchestrated and imaginatively staged, stands out.
content: It’s a change so small, you might not even notice it. But the posters and playbills around the campus of Santa Fe Opera in New Mexico have given Monteverdi a makeover: Gone is the article from “L’Orfeo,” which is being styled this summer as simply “Orfeo.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Twilight of the Serial Killer: Cases Like Gilgo Beach Become Ever Rarer
description: Serial murders have dwindled, thanks to a cautious citizenry and improved technology. But sociopaths have found new methods of mayhem.
content: Rex Heuermann, the meticulous architectural consultant who the authorities say murdered three women and buried them on a Long Island beach more than a decade ago, may have been among the last of the dying breed of American serial killers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Schumer Wields Political Heft in Bid for New York Chips Funds
description: The Senate majority leader helped deliver billions of dollars in federal funding for semiconductors. Now he’s pushing for his state to reap benefits.
content: In a darkened hotel ballroom in San Jose, Calif., last November, the most powerful players in the semiconductor industry received a familiar sales pitch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: An Ambiguous Account
description: A Times journalist observed the creation of the atomic bomb, but questions persist about his version of the events.
content: The new film “Oppenheimer” is missing a fascinating and ambiguous character.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fred Kaplan
title: Looking for Peace in the Long History of War
description: The U.C.L.A. sociologist Michael Mann seeks to uncover the causes of war across the globe, from the classical era to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
content: If wars are “the least rational of human projects,” why have there been so many of them all over the world, in every era? This is the question that the sociologist Michael Mann poses in the boldly titled “On Wars.” It is an ambitious book, plumbing the roots of war from the early Roman Republic to Vladimir Putin’s Russia, with intermediary chapters on ancient and imperial China, Mongol conquests, feudal Japan, the carnage of European Christendom, clashes in pre-Columbian and Latin America, the two world wars, colonial incursions, communist conflicts and the wars of the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times
